abstract.p: Annotated list of new architectural projects set to open this fall and winter and next year; photo (M)

block.p: Buildings
September
HALL OF JUSTICE, NANTES, FRANCE Jean Nouvel. A civil and criminal courts building by the architect of the Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Paris.

HELMUT LANG PARFUMERIE, NEW YORK; GAGOSIAN GALLERY, NEW YORK Gluckman Mayner Architects. The scent of art. The first in a quintet of new interiors designed by Richard Gluckman, the art world's favorite architect of contemplative space. New galleries for Mary Boone, Charles Cowles and the Philadelphia Museum of Art are scheduled to open in October. Monacelli Press has just published the first monograph on Mr. Gluckman's work, with an essay by Hal Foster.
October
STEALTH BUILDING, CULVER CITY, LOS ANGELES Eric Owen Moss. The latest increment in his postindustrial village.

TANG TEACHING MUSEUM AND ART GALLERY, SKIDMORE COLLEGE, SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Antoine Predock. The Tang will emphasize the interaction of older and electronic media in a building with wings that redefine the landscape.

UNITED STATES COURTHOUSE AND FEDERAL BUILDING, ISLIP, N.Y. Richard Meier. Oyez, oyez. Justice for Meier. The first of two Meier-designed buildings scheduled to open this month. A time for reappraisal after the commission of the century achievement of the Getty Center.

HUDSON, NEW YORK Philippe Starck. Ian Schrager's latest oasis of style, at 356 West 58th Street, features a year-round private garden -- a Gramercy Park for transients -- furnished with over-scaled, Alice in Wonderlandish tools. Guest rooms will feature bedside lamps with shades painted by Francesco Clemente.

SCANDINAVIA HOUSE, NEW YORK James Stewart Polshek. High design and fish-ball soup. The new headquarters and galleries for the American-Scandinavian Foundation, at 58 Park Avenue, opens with ''Nordic Design: The Generation X.''
November
INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY, NEW YORK Gwathmey Siegel & Associates. An expansion and renovation of the only art museum in the New Times Square, at 1133 Avenue of the Americas and 43rd Street.
December
TERMINUS HOENHEIM-NORD, STRASBOURG, FRANCE Zaha Hadid. A tramway station and parking for 800 cars, part of the city's new Line B.

BELLEVUE ART MUSEUM, BELLEVUE, WASH. Steven Holl. A street fair that morphed into a museum, the design features outdoor terraces and circuitous circulation through the system. The museum, which will have no permanent collection, is described by its director, Diane Douglas, as an intersection between art, science and technology.
January

STUDENT ARTS CENTER, JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, BALTIMORE Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. Designed to bring art into an environment dedicated to science, the Student Arts Center creates a new campus landscape with courtyards, paths and views.
DG BANK BUILDING, BERLIN Frank Gehry. The one with the horse-head conference room in the middle.

BASS MUSEUM OF ART, MIAMI BEACH Arata Isozaki. The centerpiece of a new cultural complex on Collins Avenue at 21st Street that includes a new theater by Arquitectonica and a library by Robert A. M. Stern.
April
CONCERT HALL AND EXHIBITION COMPLEX, ROUEN, FRANCE Bernard Tschumi. Sports as well as musical events will be held in the new 7,000-seat hall, which features an asymmetrical floor plan.

TRUMP WORLD TOWER, NEW YORK Costas Kondylis. Let's give 'em something to talk about. The 70-story building rising near the United Nations on First Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets purportedly compelled City Hall to propose new zoning restrictions on the height of skyscrapers. But Donald Trump's latest deal may turn out to be a transitional building between the great glass skyscrapers of the 1960's and the next generation of tall buildings that will rise when New York overcomes its present affliction with vertigo.
MAY

MILWAUKEE ART MUSEUM The first built project in the United States by the Spaniard Santiago Calatrava, the world's pre-eminent architect-engineer, is an addition to a museum housed in buildings by Eero Saarinen and David Kahler. A companion exhibition will be held in Dallas at the Meadows Museum, Southern Methodist University, opening in March.
MEDIAPARK BLOCK 1, COLOGNE, GERMANY Jean Nouvel. A mixed-use building complex incorporating housing, schools, hotels, offices and shops.

INTERNATIONAL ARRIVALS BUILDING, KENNEDY INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, NEW YORK Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Air travel will continue to be hopeless in our lifetimes -- neither the government nor the airlines care one whit about our comfort -- but at least the moving platforms in this building will offer an installation by Diller and Scofidio featuring panels with lenticular screens.
June
MEDIATHEQUE, SENDAI, JAPAN Toyo Ito. This long-awaited project explores the prospects for public space in an era dominated by communications technology.
July

PRADA, SOHO, NEW YORK Rem Koolhaas. The Pritzker Prize winner, author of ''The Harvard Guide to Shopping'' and rumored co-star (with Matt Damon) of a forthcoming major motion picture, reveals the deeper mysteries of the upscale retail experience.
Exhibitions
September
''THE OPULENT EYE OF ALEXANDER GIRARD'' Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, New York. Textiles, furniture and tableware from a master of mid-20th-century modern design. Sept. 12 through March 18.
''MAYA LIN: BETWEEN ART AND ARCHITECTURE'' Cooper Union for the Advancement of Art and Science, Cooper Square, New York. Sept. 26 through Nov. 17.

''THE WORLD'S MOST EXPENSIVE PUBLIC SPACE'' Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, New York. The Municipal Art Society offers a wry survey of New York's 503 privately owned public spaces. Sept. 29 through Nov.18.
October
''OTHER PLANS'' Reynolds Club, University of Chicago. Michael Sorkin. A vision for the architecturally controversial campus by the noted maverick designer. Oct. 3 through Oct. 23.
''ABITARE IL TEMPO'' International Exhibition of Design and Decoration, Verona, Italy. Presentations on the Classic, the Urban Fragment, the Sensual Home and World Design. Opens Oct. 12.
''SANTIAGO CALATRAVA: ARTIST, ARCHITECT, ENGINEER'' Palazzo Strozzi, Florence. Calatrava has duende. Oct. 5 through Jan. 7.

''THE LONG VIEW'' Urban Center. A joint production of the Municipal Art Society and the Museum of Modern Art, the show presents Philip Johnson's latest selection of fresh young talent. It includes projects by Jesse Reiser and Naneko Umemoto, Ben van Berkel and Carolyn Bos, and Michael Maltzen, presented one at a time over a 10-week stretch. Oct. 6 through Dec. 9.
January

''SUITE FANTASTIQUE'' The Wexner Center, Columbus, Ohio. Four shows, curated by Jeffrey Kipnis, featuring works by Rem Koolhaas, Daniel Libeskind, Bernard Tschumi, Scott Burton, Thom Mayne and others. Jan. 26 through April 15. A must!
February

''SHAPING THE GREAT CITY: MODERN ARCHITECTURE IN CENTRAL EUROPE, 1890-1937'' Getty Center, Los Angeles. An astonishingly great survey of urban visions as the cities of the Hapsburg Empire looked toward modern times. Originally organized by the Canadian Center for Architecture. Feb. 20 through May 6.

''WORKSPHERES'' Museum of Modern Art, New York. The future of the workplace in the world of laptops and cell phones. How do you set up borders in the era of 24/7? Or is the collapse of borders the whole point? Because of the museum's expansion, the exhibition will include other sites around town, to be announced. Feb. 8 through May 8.
May

''JOHN SOANE, ARCHITECT: MASTER OF SPACE AND LIGHT'' Canadian Center for Architecture, Montreal. The only North American venue of an ambitious show dedicated to an architect whose ideas framed issues that endure today. May 9 through Sept. 9.

''FRANK O. GEHRY: THE ART OF ARCHITECTURE'' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York. A reckoning. Drawings, models, constructions will fill the rotunda and several side galleries of the Wright building. Dates to be set.
June

''MIES IN AMERICA'' Whitney Museum of American Art, New York. Organized by Phyllis Lambert, founding director of the Canadian Center for Architecture and the force behind Mies van der Rohe's greatest work, the Seagram Building. Documents the architect's work between 1938 and his death in 1969. May 9 through Sept. 9.
''VENTURI, SCOTT BROWN & ASSOCIATES: ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN Philadelphia Museum of Art. Work by the duo who taught architects how to learn. June 10 through Aug. 5.
Compiled with the assistance of Anna Bahney.
